description: From Old French reclus, past participle of reclure, from Latin reclūdere, present active infinitive of reclūdō (“I disclose, I open”), from re- + claudō (“close”).

adjectives.description: recluse (comparative more recluse, superlative most recluse)

entries.meaning: a person who lives in self-imposed isolation or seclusion from the world, especially for religious purposes; a hermit
examples: The recluse in the fable kept a cat to keep off the rats, and then a cow to feed the cat with milk, and a man to keep the cow and so on. My ambitions also grew like the family of the recluse.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) the place where a recluse dwells; a place of isolation or seclusion
examples: that day of appearance taken out of the recluse and committed to safe custody

verbs.description: recluse (third-person singular simple present recluses, present participle reclusing, simple past and past participle reclused)
